ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My Chinese speaking and writing skills were greatly improved. I also have a more developed understanding of Chinese culture and history.
I got an hour of immersion in Chinese everyday, and better speaking, writing, and especially reading skills.
I was able to greatly improve my reading, writing, and speaking skills in Chinese.
Improved my Chinese --expanded vocab, learned more formal grammatical patterns, and characters.
learned a lot more formal chinese grammar structures, culture, and societal problems

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course teaches Chinese very well. My Chinese improved so much since starting 132, and I'm so glad to have taken these courses. I can now hold conversations in Chinese better and read a lot of Chinese writing.
Generally the course is set up to improve your Chinese without you even noticing, even if you put in just a little effort.

This course increases in rigor quite a bit from 132 and was not expecting to go from basic words and one or two lessons a week to complex vocabulary-heavy lessons every two to three days. However, Liu Laoshi was very understanding and sympathetic, and always checked in to make sure we were managing well.

Liu laoshi is amazing! She truly wants everyone to succeed and is always there if you need extra help. The course was well organized and feedback was readily available. The chapters were fun, but sometimes felt like we moved a little fast --though still doable.
it would've been better in person. for an online class, it was really good

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All lessons were live and in-person, and class participation was highly encouraged. There were also weekly tutoring sessions to practice even more. This course adjusted well.
The weekly tutorials were great and helped a lot.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. It teaches Chinese very well. If you want to improve your speaking and writing skills in Chinese, take this class.
I would recommend this to any heritage student. Even if you plan to take another language at Yale, add this course (it's really not that hard to scrape by and get an A).

I think if you look ahead at the calendars and organize your time well, then yes! I love Chinese because it provides a sense of consistency and routine that you don't necessarily get in college and in other courses.
Yes! Definitely! This course was really fun and amazing. It is super well organized and Liu laoshi is the best! You learn a lot throughout your time in the class and improvement is clear.
yes. if you want to learn chinese, take this class. It's faster than 132, but you learn a lot.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: included thursday asynchronous classes and discussion posts
